content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B {B}. The reason for this choice is based on considering the long-term payoff over the 75 rounds of the game.

If both players play R {R}, each round results in a payout of 45$, but since there are 75 rounds, the total payout would be $3675 for each player (75 * 45$). However, if one or both players switch to strategy B {B} after some initial rounds, they can potentially gain more overall.

If a player consistently plays B {B}, they will get 40$ in 60 out of the 75 rounds (since their opponent must respond with R {R} because of the game rules), resulting in a total payout of $2400 for that strategy. Additionally, if there is an opportunity to exploit the other player by responding with R {R} when the other player chooses R {R}, they can earn 35$ in those particular rounds, while the other player gets nothing. This could potentially increase the total payout for strategy B {B} above the $2400 base payout.

Therefore, it seems that consistently playing strategy B {B} over the long run provides a higher potential payout than sticking with R {R}. Of course, it's important to note that this reasoning assumes the other player is rational and follows the same thought process, which may not always be the case in practice.

This is higher than the previous payout of $2400 when consistently playing B {B}. However, if my opponent switches their strategy and starts choosing R {R} after this round, I will earn only 40$ for each round they switch (60 out of the remaining 74 rounds), resulting in a total payout of $2400.

It's important to remember that this reasoning assumes my opponent is rational and follows the same thought process as me. In practice, opponents may not always be rational or follow the same strategies, but this approach can help guide our decision-making in this repeated game scenario.
